review_title: Relative decent pay, but very poor Covid handling
job_title: Part-time Instructor in High Point, NC
pros: Decent pay compared to other schools in the area, but without benefits for part-time employees. The students are pretty decent.
cons: HPU leadership has done a very poor job at handling the ongoing pandemic and would rather bury their heads in the sand and pretend that doing anything to counteract spreading the virus is an infringement on individual rights (can anyone tell me where the right to spreading airborne infectious is located in our constitution, please?). As an employee, I feel treated like a cogs in a machine rather than a human being that rightfully worries about taking this new airborne virus home to my family. There is a complete lack of transparency from the University with professors about anonymous student infection rates, there is NO contact tracing with us professors when students in our classes get Covid (although we are expected to not social distance from them and it is impossible to do so in most classrooms anyways), students are NOT required to mask up UNLESS there is a county mandate, and there is NO transparency or requirement of FDA-approved vaccination for anyone. The total lack of concern for public health (and for the local community in particular) and lack of transparency of university cases are extremely concerning and offensive. What are they teaching these poor, young students about civic duty and about being socially conscious?

job_title: Anonymous Employee in High Point, NC
pros:
The people! I am happy to say I am good friends with the people I work with. I enjoy coming to work every day. The culture of the University is a very positive one. Their values are clearly visible and emphasized in almost everything they do. They look out for their students, faculty, and staff. Also plenty of growth potential. The University has grown remarkably over the last 10 years, defying the recession, and is poised to do the same for the next 10 years. As they continue to earn recognition and attract greater talent, this can only benefit current and future employees.

This is really a place where you can enjoy what you do and feel like you are a valuable part of a team that is making a difference in people's lives in higher education.
cons: The compensation and benefits are somewhat lackluster beyond all of the gifts and "free stuff." Average or below average pay in most fields, but this is almost to be expected at an institution whose primary goal is to educate their students. If you don't "buy in" to their mission and values, it will all seem a little lacking to you.

job_title: Faculty Member in High Point, NC
pros: Beautiful campus; Lots of perks including free gifts such as iPads, Go-Pro cameras, bonus checks, and free steak dinners; fantastic colleagues at the departmental level; health care, vision, dental and other benefits; generous match on retirement plan; professional development funds available
cons: Micromanaging deans; unreasonable expectation to pass students who are unable to master course materials; contractual obligation to be on campus 5 days a week; administration values teaching and university service over research and other scholarly activities; criticism of the school, administration or any other aspect of the institution is seen as "insubordination" and individuals who express opinions contrary to the administration will experience reprisals; faculty are expected to follow "customer service" model, attend admissions open houses and are required to be on campus for Saturday scholarship interviews; Faculty pressured to help move freshmen into dorms; FERPA forms allow parents to call faculty whenever they feel like it (I felt more like an elementary school teacher than a professor); President promises parents "we will take care of your children"; salary is below national and state averages across the board; pressure from administration to live in the city of High Point; pressure to contribute to United Way; focus is on retention rather than education.

review_title: Sad to leave. But I had to go.
job_title: Assistant in High Point, NC
pros: The ability to grow within an organization, is an environment I THRIVE in. At High Point University that is the exact work environment I was a part of. Unfortunately my significant other got accepted to Law School in another state, so we had to move. I am currently looking for a job, but not in Higher Education because I KNOW that it won't be anything like High Point University! The way the President is hands on with all of the projects within the University is unreal, I am not quite sure the man is human. President Qubein is an Extraordinary Leader for all of High Point. I was just glad to be a part of it. At High Point I felt like I was part of a family, and more importantly a team with one goal...the students.
cons: The only con...is if you can't keep up in the fast paced environment that is and makes High Point University the Higher Education institution that it is today!

review_title: Good for high performance academics who prefer innovation-action to faculty governance
job_title: Department Head in High Point, NC
pros: Ability to make things happen and accomplish goals at rapid pace and without intense bueracracy. If you are interested in growth and continuous improvement, it's an amazing place to be. Incredible community support from business and local leaders. Culture is more private-corporate with high expectations for inventive, energetic leadership.
cons: Culture is more private-corporate, so faculty can feel as though they have little voice or control over their futures. There is often anxiety over student-parent interactions and intense burnout from heavy demands on personal time--mostly in recruiting efforts. Can be difficult for families. While requirement to publish is low-this can disadvantage an academic who invests so much in students there is little time or energy left for scholarship. If you are not a workaholic, HPU, or ACADEMIA may not be a good fit for you.

job_title: IT Helpdesk in High Point, NC
pros: When most days you are able to pinch yourself and ask the question, do I get paid to do this? That's when you know you are surrounded by a great work environment. The projects can be overwhelming, but when you break it down day by day it starts to become easier to achieve success. I throughly enjoy working with students on a daily basis and ultimately become a solution finder on a daily basis (not a problem solver!).
cons: In IT there seems to be a lot of turnover, which can be a negative but can also be a positive as we will be adding fresh eyes and new ideas to our team. Sometimes it's challenging working at the helpdesk, but again I turn it into customer service for our students here at HPU.

job_title: Chemistry Lecturer in High Point, NC
pros:
Nice looking campus, and there are many decent teachers and instructors.
The students were nice, and I got the best student reviews in the department, even though, as an adjunct, most of the tenure track people wouldn't give me the time of day.
cons:
I worked as a chemistry teacher. The chemistry department is worse than you'd see in a poor third world country. The new head of the department is a physicist, with scant knowledge of chemistry. There is NO modern equipment. I told the head of the department that the condition of the department "bordered on fraud". He didn't disagree. This place is a mess, and a massive waste of time and money.
HPU is a pretty cake with lots of frosting. The administration is nasty, tightfisted, authoritarian, and clueless. I am embarrassed for having been a part of this debacle.

review_title: Progressive University for the Progressive Minded
job_title: Assistant Professor in High Point, NC
pros: No red tape to slow down the implentation of ideas. My dean is supportive and the resources that surround faculty and students enrich the learning environment.  Some of my "seasoned" colleagues might prefer the old liberal arts model, but I appreciate, and my advisees seem th thrive in, this campus of innovation.  HPU should be featured in Fast Company. Our Provost promotes mentoring and collaborative learning approaches with our students. These are not only efffective teaching models, as an instructor, it is liberating to have the space to test new concepts.
cons: not enough opportunites for collaboration between faculty across disciplines - would like structure for departments to mingle more often

job_title: Administration in High Point, NC
pros: Awesome work environment, great benefits and extra perks such as bonus structure and money added to your passport card every semester for food and other items.  The campus is unreal. Almost like working in a resort that happens to hold classes.  The management staff seems genuinely invested in the success of the students and institution.
cons: Parents and students can be very rude and condescending towards staff when it comes to payment and tuition issues. Often treated like an illiterate hillbilly by some parents that call or visit because of their 1% status. Interdepartmental relations could be better.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in High Point, NC
pros: Feels like you are contributing to important work. The entire community cares about student success and enhancing the experience for students as they learn.  extra perks like $ on company ID card for meals, etc (like a debit card). Bonus when institution does well. Monthly staff meetings keep everyone informed on the direction of the school and allows staff to recognize each other.  I like that culture of teamwork. I know there are similar meetings with faculty and the auxilliary workers.
cons: parking is challenging - they have growth of students and faculty/staff.

review_title: Join the cult or get out now.
job_title: in High Point, NC
pros: Attractive (but cramped) campus; good benefits; really good food options; friendly (but cynical)  faculty.  Parking was free and campus security was acceptable when students were in residence.
cons:
Recently HP evolved (devolved?) from a sleepy liberal arts college into a showy "boutique" university that caters mostly to upper-middle class students from affluent families.  Internally, these students are known as "full-pays," and the admissions office courts them almost exclusively.  As such, campus diversity suffers, and students with serious academic goals are left feeling isolated and unchallenged  (the bulk of whom transfer after one or two semesters).

The biggest problem with HPU is the school's educational philosophy: the buyer is always right.  Students and their wealthy parents are catered to non-stop with a whirlwind of exciting activities in glamorous surroundings.  There is pressure to inflate grades (frustrating for faculty) and even more pressure to overlook bad behavior outside of the classroom (frustrating for staff).  "Helicoptering" is not just encouraged, it's celebrated.  Students graduate with a degree, few academic challenges, and a tremendous sense of entitlement.  All of the employees play a role in it, and no one feels really good about it. 

What most surprised me about HPU was the "Office of WOW."    The job of the WOW office is to entertain the student body 24/7 with anything and everything their hearts desire.  Most have no problem with such a concept until they realize just how much time and money go into keeping the students spoiled and happy.  This office was added in past few years, and is probably the reason the campus has such an amusement park type of atmosphere. 
  
As a member of the faculty, one should expect a lot of private cynicism from one's peers as well as a sense of dread.  Tenured faculty are paid well, but the rest fall short of regional standards.  New faculty members are put through an orientation program that says all the right things, but no one warns you about the lack of intellectual curiosity from the students or the appalling interference from parents with respect to grades, class attendance, and assignments.  Upper administration encourages this, so there's very little faculty can do to stop it.  
 
For staff, the outlook is much worse.  Most of the longtime staff members who survived the transition in 2005 are clearly burned out from 70-hr work weeks.  Starting salaries are below the regional average and turnover is high.  I have never met a more stressed-out group of people in my life.  Those who stay tend to be young and inexperienced.  New staff members with previous experience elsewhere tended to leave quickly and quietly.  The biggest issue seemed to be upper management's inability to understand how many hours staffers put in.  The emphasis is to be "lean" within each office but to cater to every student's need at the same time.  The result is far too many staffers working until 9 or 10 pm or all weekend just to keep up.   
 
My experience was that HPU functions with a very top-down approach to leadership and management.  The University's president and a few VPs hold all of the authority.  I sat on a couple of key committees, but we were powerless with respect to making changes or recommendations for reform.  All changes come from above, and there is a certain air to new directives: Embrace this or please leave.

job_title: Faculty in High Point, NC
pros: A beautiful campus and getting more so, but it has a "new" look and feel that makes it seem artificial.  The students are pleasant and most of the faculty members were friendly to me right away.
cons:
I served in a non-tenured faculty position (FT) for approximately 3 semesters and departed High Point for a tenure-track position at a similar institution in 2009.  I don't regret my stay at HPU, but I don't strongly recommend it as a place to work either.  At HPU, the student is King, so ultimately anyone signing on (in any position) should be aware that potential disputes usually result with a ruling in favor of the student.  This includes honor code violations, but typically excludes retention issues with respect to minimum GPA standards.  Salaries are very low at HPU, but there was some attempt to offer better benefits to bolster the money issues.  Newcomers will be surprised at the low wages because the campus is dripping with luxurious ammenities, and the students want for nothing.  (Even the dorms have swimming pools, and singles for freshmen are apparently common.)  Academic supervisors are sympathetic and will say so, but they don't have much decision-making power with respect to budgets.  

Town/Gown issues were significant as well during my stay.  The city of High Point is not affluent, and if you happen to live in one of the local neighborhoods, as I did, you may find a lot of resentment directed at the University, its rapid growth, and/or the omnipresence of the students.  The school solved its "landlocked" issues by purchasing hundreds of homes and tearing them down, replacing them with student housing and greek houses.  The HPU brand is everywhere, and the local media usually cover the issues with a bias that is always sympathetic to the university.  I think this tendency frustrates local residents and business owners.

Frustration can set in for any employee who takes the time to look around and absorb the campus environment.  HPU is a very student-friendly campus.  The staff engages them constantly, and it would not be wrong to assume that at HPU what goes on outside of the classroom is viewed as more important than what goes on inside the classroom.  It was not uncommon for me to find that students had skipped my classes (even exams) to attend a campus event or to hangout in the students' fitness center.  I had the impression that the staff in the Student Life & Activities area were extremely overworked and very underappreciated.  They worked a lot on the weekends and at nights.  On most Saturdays, the admissions office "owned" the campus.  That division of HPU is a marketing machine.  Be prepared to do your part.  Saying no is not usually an option.

review_title: High Point University strives to provide the best experience for students inside and outside of the classroom.
job_title: Assistant Director of Greek Life and Resident Director in High Point, NC
pros: High Point University offers its employees many different incentives to work hard.  There is a constant push for innovation and a strong focus on providing a consistent brand through positive customer service.
cons: Within my office, there is a strong divide between some of the supervisors and other staff.  Sometimes there are challenges in explaining expectations for position that can later create tension between employees and their supervisors.

job_title: Resident Assistant in High Point, NC
pros: The RDs are for the most part really cool people, there's some obvious benefits for being an RA (like living alone). However, working with the other people on your staff is so much fun. Your staff is like your family and it's great to be able to share the best duty night stories with them.
cons: The higher ups can be very strict and put limits on the RDs interaction with us. Don't really have a say in what form you're in until your second year either.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in High Point, NC
pros: Great perks of traveling is that you can keep your hotel, rental car, & airline points. Have the opportunity to visit places you would not have gone to otherwise. If you are a graduate of the school, it is easy to talk about and connect with students.
cons: Can have poor communication within the office. They are attempting to work on that and are improving on office morale. The group of people I work with now are the best we've ever had in this office.

job_title: Communications Manager in High Point, NC
pros: Work is important, dynamic and fulfilling at HPU. Pace is quick and changes daily, so there is never a dull moment. But staff are also supported, guided and yet given autonomy and room for creativity. Those who want new opportunities will find them here.
cons: You need to be flexible. That is not bad - just means it isn't for everyone if you cannot change and adapt quickly.

job_title: Shuttle Driver in High Point, NC
pros: Great comradire with co-workers. Work was easy. Free meals.
cons: Manager stinks. Human Resources useless. Extraordinary claims are false. Overindulged students and their parents money run the school. No rules if you have money. One call from mommy and they get what the want.

review_title: Great as a stepping stone, not so great for the long haul.

pros:
good training opportunities
beautiful campus with security patrols
good number of paid holidays and time off
very energetic atmosphere
dining cards given twice a year
Gifts during some staff meetings
cons:

job_title: Enterprise Applications Specialist in High Point, NC
pros: The cafeteria is pretty legit, they serve ice cream every day.  The people around campus are generally nice to work with, and there is a lot of pretty decent free HPU swag.  I would still be there if I worked in another department.  Campus is also beautiful, but it is hard to enjoy the flowers if you're being abused in IT.
cons:
IT is terrible.  There are not words for how bad IT has become in the last 3 years.  Top level management is dreadful; they are unable to manage projects, train employees, retain knowledge, or provide for the needs of campus.  The treatment of employees is deplorable.  Employees are cussed out, the CIO constantly threats to fire people or strangle them, and staff are regularly subjected to inappropriate, unprofessional, and abusive rants, both in person and via email.  Also, don't expect to ever know when you will be allowed to go home every day (that's right, you're an adult but you're not allowed to leave if a team member is working on a problem that you have nothing to do with).  As a result of poor project management and insanely high turnover (well over 50% at my last count), something is on fire literally every day.  If you arrive at 8:30 and leave at 5, you will be publicly humiliated.  And HR doesn't think that threatening to strangle employees is a hostile work environment, so good luck getting any help improving the conditions.

Basically, if you want to be treated like a human being and advance your career at the same time, while also not becoming an alcoholic, look somewhere else.

job_title: Chef in High Point, NC
pros: I absolutely loved providing one-hundred percent customer satisfaction.  It was my passion to go above and beyond the call of duty to serve our clients.
cons: I would desire more team work for the outcome of our clients, and less employee and management turn over.

review_title: The Grass Isn't Greener! I want to go back to HPU
job_title: Information Technology in High Point, NC
pros: the clear mission to help students succeed. the environment. the faculty and staff.  the students. the cultural events. the basketball games. the president's talks. nice gifts employees receive
cons: sometimes parking. being on call for possible technical issues. periods of extreme business

review_title: Be ready to work your butt off!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in High Point, NC
pros: You believe you are truly working to help students.  Most of the students you work with are incredibly sweet and competent.
cons: You work 50+ hours every week.  Be prepared to work numerous weekends.  If one person has to be there, everyone has to be there.

review_title: An exciting university for those who need challenges in order to be fullfilled.
job_title: Work With Students in High Point, NC
pros: innovation is appreciated. Environment is unmatched! Bureaucracy doesn't slow you down. Great opportunities to contribute no matter what dept. you are in.
cons: Not for me, but seems the thread of cons here deals with expectations.  I like a challenge and appreciate the fact that HPU expects contribituions at all levels.

job_title: Survey Research Center Supervisor in High Point, NC
pros: Freedom, good pay for a student job, good bosses, relaxed atmosphere.  Nothing to complain about if you did your work.
cons: There weren't many bad things about HPU student jobs.  Sometimes the survey research center was boring if people weren't taking the surveys.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in High Point, NC
pros: Great campus, engaged students, general account added every semester, located in North Carolina
cons: Overworked. Employees are told not to complain. Very high turnover. No professional growth opportunities. No work life balance. If you don't agree with senior leadership you are cast aside. Says its known for creativity and innovation but employees ideas are not listened to and leadership just does what they want. Way to much focus on Nido. Compensation is not great including both faculty and staff. Just look at the schools 990 form for a better insight.

job_title: Resident Assistant in High Point, NC
pros: Complimentary room & board, $390 a month, single room, meet lots of people (residents, and fellow RAs), good work experience
cons: Lots of poorly planned training sessions, hard to have a social life, inconsistent Resident Directors, usually had a negative misrepresentation, seemed like we dealt with more student problems than security did.

job_title: Professional Staff in High Point, NC
pros: Beautiful surroundings and an educated workforce.
cons: Family values and work life balance preached, but not practiced.

job_title: Adjunct Instructor in High Point, NC
pros: HPU is growing quickly and spends a lot of money on new construction and building programs. Beautiful campus and great facilities. Administration is open to new ideas and has a "make it happen" mindset.
cons: No cons. HPU is a fantastic place to work.

job_title: IT Specialist in High Point, NC
pros: Great Campus and good perks.
cons: Low pay, and the President tells how much money he raises as he announces a 1% COLA.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Palm Harbor, FL
pros: As a student, great opportunity to develop some strong skills that are needed in the workforce. Developed many meaningful relationships with students, other resident assistants, and staff.
cons:
Training for position could be reviewed and updated
Low retention rate for Resident Director position

job_title: Facility Manager in High Point, NC
pros: Flexible work hours, good management, easy tasks to complete, easy to balance school and work
cons: Not always the best in organization, sometimes people didn't show up for work, no chance for promotions

job_title: Security in High Point, NC
pros: it has good benefits and bounus
cons: upper management likes to micro manage

job_title: Resident Assistant in High Point, NC
pros: The people are awesome and they really want you to build professional connections.
cons: Sometimes specific dates are not communicated well and leave some RA's out to dry

job_title: Assistant Director in High Point, NC
pros:
-positive environment 
-great students
-nice “perks”
cons:
-low salary
-no work life balance

job_title: Academic Tutor in High Point, NC
pros: Very flexible hours, work around your schedule.
cons: Once you set your schedule, it is near impossible to adjust until the next semester.

review_title: A great environment to work in, beautiful campus and wonderful people.
job_title: Campus Concierge in High Point, NC
pros: The campus is beautiful and the environment is exciting.
cons: The pay is not satisfactory.

job_title: Lab Technician in Winston-Salem, NC
pros: Flexible with schedule and usually nice bosses
cons: Not offered enough hours to make working worth it

job_title: International Ambassador in High Point, NC
pros: Flexible hours, kind faculty and staff
cons: Not always the best guidance for conducted projects

review_title: "I can find someone else to do your job"
job_title: Resident Director in High Point, NC
pros: Beautiful space. Hard working people.
cons: Employees are valued only superficially in staff meetings etc. On the ground it is a regular occurrence in several departments to be yelled at or belittled once a week.

job_title: Resident Assistant in High Point, NC
pros: Subsidized housing, good community, transferable skills
cons: Frustrating to work for Office of Student Life

job_title: Anonymous Employee in High Point, NC
pros: Great experience and coaching given
cons: Lots of rotating employees each semester

job_title: Security Officer in High Point, NC
pros: great people to work with
cons: upper management is all about themselves

job_title: Faculty in High Point, NC
pros: A good place as a transition.
cons: Not the place to settle into.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in High Point, NC
pros: - Flexible schedule and Discounted Housing
cons: - Work a lot of weekends

job_title: Anonymous Employee in High Point, NC
pros: Housing was the best part
cons: RD's were not always understanding

job_title: Tour Guide in High Point, NC
pros: Fun meeting new people on tours
cons: Nothing but sometimes repetitive work

job_title: in Raleigh, NC
pros: There are not pros to working for them.
